question: '19' is related to '360' following a certain logic. Following the same logic, '36' is related to '1295'. Which of the following numbers is related to '783' using the same logic?
solution:
19 is coded as (19)² - 1 = 361 - 1 = 360

36 is coded as (36)² - 1 = 1296 - 1 = 1295

Similarly,

28 is coded as (28)² - 1 = 784 - 1 = 783

So, option (d) is the correct answer.

(The words must be considered as meaningful English words and must NOT be related to each other based on the number of letter/number of consonants/vowels in the word.)
solution:
As Piano is a Instrument. Similarly, Jazz is a Genre.

So, option (a) is the correct answer.

question:

2[(14 ÷ 4) - (4 x 3)] - 3[(9 ÷ 3) - 64 ÷ 7] = 13

What will come in the place of the question mark (?) in the following equation, if '÷' and '+' are interchanged and '-' and 'x' are interchanged?

56 ÷ (14 + 7) x 8 - 2 = ?
solution:
56 ÷ (14 + 7) x 8 - 2 = ?

After the interchange of signs:

56 + (14 ÷ 7) - 8 x 2 = ?

56 + 2 - 16 = ?

58 - 16 = ?

? = 42

So, option (c) is the correct answer.

question:

Some wheat are rice.

All rice are grams.

option_3: Only conclusions I and II follow
solution:

Some wheat are rice. All rice are grams. Some pulses are grams.

The basic minimum overlapping and another possible diagrams are,

Here, some grams are wheat, there is no direct relationship between wheat and pulses, and some rice being pulses is a possibility.

Hence, only conclusion III follows.

question:
Which numbers will replace question mark (?) in the following series?

0.5, 0.5, 2, 18, 288, ?
In a certain code language, 'WHITE' is coded as '260' and 'BROWN' is coded as '288'. How will 'OLIVE' be coded in that language?
solution:
A (1)B (2)C (3)D (4)E (5)F (6)G (7)H (8)I (9)J (10)K (11)L (12)M (13)
Z (26)Y (25)X (24)W (23)V (22)U (21)T (20)S (19)R (18)Q (17)P (16)O (15)N (14)

Here, the pattern is:

'WHITE' is coded as '260' -

W (23), H (8), I (9), T (20), E (5)

23 + 8 + 9 + 20 + 5 = 65 X 4 = 260

'BROWN' is coded as '288' -

B (2), R (18), O (15), W (23), N (14)

2 + 18 + 15 + 23 + 14 = 72 X 4 = 288

Similarly,

'OLIVE' will be written as -

O (15), L (12), I (9), V (22), E (5)

15 + 12 + 9 + 22 + 5 = 63 X 4 = 252

question:
Select the correct option that indicates the arrangement of the given words in a logical and meaningful order.

1) Month

2) Semi-centennial

3) Century

4) Decade

5) Week

6) Year
solution: The unit of time in increasing order is Week (7 days) < Month (28-31 days) < Year (12 months) < Decade (10 Years) < Semi-centennial (50 years) < Century (100 Years).

question:
Read the given statements and conclusions carefully. Assuming that the information given in the statements is true, even if it appears to be at variance with the commonly known facts, decide which of the given conclusions logically follow(s) from the statements.

Statements:

All brunch is lunch.

Some breakfast is dinner.

No lunch is breakfast.

Conclusions:

I. Some brunch is dinner.

II. Some lunch is dinner.

III. No lunch is dinner.
option_2: Both conclusion I and II follow
option_4: Either conclusion II or III follow
solution:
From the given statements, the Venn diagram is:

Here, there is a possibility that some brunch is dinner. So, conclusion I is false.

Here, there is a possibility that some lunch is dinner. So, conclusion II and III are false.

Also, conclusion II is positive and conclusion III is negative statements. So, either II or III follows.

question:
In a certain code language,

'A $ B' means 'A is the wife of B',

'A # B' means 'A is the sister of B',

'A & B' means 'A is the son of B',

'A % B means 'A is the father of B',

'A * B means 'A is the mother-in-law of B'.

As per which of the following expression, 'K is the mother of H'?
solution:
It is given that,

'A $ B' means 'A is the wife of B',

'A # B' means 'A is the sister of B',

'A & B' means 'A is the son of B',

'A % B means 'A is the father of B',

'A * B means 'A is the mother-in-law of B'.

Option (a) H # G & K

After decoding, we get:

H is the sister of G. G is the son of K.

Here, K is either mother or father of H. So, option (a) is incorrect.

Option (b) K & G * H

After decoding, we get:

K is the son of G. G is the mother-in-law of H.

Here, K is the husband or brother-in-law of H. So, option (b) is incorrect.

Option (c) H # L $ K

After decoding, we get:

H is the sister of L. L is the wife of K.

Here, K is the brother-in-law of H. so, option (c) is incorrect.

Option (d) K * L $ H

After decoding, we get:

K is the mother-in-law of L. L is the wife of H.

So, K is the mother of H. So, option (d) is correct.


https://u1.oliveboard.in/exams/solution/oliveimg/p24088/image001.jpg
https://u1.oliveboard.in/exams/solution/oliveimg/p24088/image002.jpg
https://u1.oliveboard.in/exams/solution/oliveimg/p24088/image003.jpg
https://u1.oliveboard.in/exams/solution/oliveimg/p24088/image004.jpg

question: Kati Bihu is an auspicious harvest festival celebrated in the month of _____
solution:
The people of Assam celebrate the auspicious harvest festival of Kati Bihu.

It is marked annually on the first day of the Kati month in the Assamese calendar and usually falls during mid-October.

The festival, also known as Kongali Bihu, marks a crucial phase of the year for every farmer's family in Assam - the fresh start of the harvest season and the relocation time of rice saplings.

It is rooted in the rural households' deep ethos related to crops and their yield.

It honours the service and penance of the people as they hope for a better future.

Though Kati Bihu is celebrated with much pomp across Assam, each tribe has their own interpretation and rituals.

Generally, people light lamps outside their homes and create pathways with bamboo to welcome their ancestors.

People also worship the Goddess Lakshmi and Tulsi plant for a good harvest.

question: In Pradhan Mantri Gramin Awaas Yojana, the cost of unit assistance is shared between Central and State Governments in the ratio ___________ for the North-Eastern and the Himalayan states.
solution:
In the Pradhan Mantri Gramin Awaas Yojana (PMAY-G), the cost of unit assistance is shared between the Central and State Governments in the ratio of 90:10 for the North-Eastern and Himalayan states.

To address these gaps in the rural housing program and in view of Governments commitment to providing "Housing for All" by the scheme 2022, Indira Awaas Yojana(IAY) has been re-structured into Pradhan Mantri Awaas Yojana Gramin (PMAY-G) w.e.f. 1st April 2016.

The cost of unit assistance is to be shared between Central and State Government in the ratio 60:40 in plain areas and 90:10 for North Eastern and the Himalayan States.

question: Which of the following expression is true with regard to Market Price(MP)?
option_1: MP= Factor cost + Indirect Taxes - Subsidies
option_2: MP= Factor cost - Indirect Taxes - Subsidies
option_3: MP= Indirect Taxes - Subsidies - Factor cost
option_4: MP= Indirect Taxes + Subsidies + Factor cost
solution:
Market Price= Factor cost + Indirect Taxes - Subsidies

Market Price (MP) refers to the price at which product is actually sold in the market. Net Indirect Taxes (NIT) is the difference between indirect taxes and subsidies. Factor Cost (FC) refers to amount paid to factors of production for their contribution in the production process.

Indirect Taxes are the taxes which are levied by the government on production and sale of commodity. Sales tax, excise duty, custom duty, etc. are some of the indirect taxes, and subsidies are the cash grants given by the government to the enterprises to encourage production of certain commodities, to promote exports or to sell goods at prices lower than the free market Price.

question: Who is India's first female professional Tabla player and the founder of the first ever all-female Indian Classical music band, Stree Shakti in 1996?
solution: Anuradha Pal, the disciple of Ustad Alla Rakha and Zakir Hussain, is globally renowned for her articulation, rhythmic artistry and virtuosic repertoire. She became India's first female professional Tabla player. She founded the first ever all-female Indian Classical music band, Stree Shakti in 1996.

question: When was "Experiments on Plant Hybridization", the seminal paper by Gregor Mendel published?
solution: The genetic experiments Gregor Mendel did with pea plants took him eight years (1856-1863) and he published his results in 1866. On February 8, 1865, Mendel presented his work to the Brunn Society for Natural Science. His paper, "Experiments on Plant Hybridization," was published the next year in 1866.

question: Ustad Qamruddin "Bismillah" Khan was an Indian musician credited with popularizing the:
solution: Ustad Qamruddin "Bismillah" Khan (born as Qamaruddin Khan), often referred to by the title Ustad, was an Indian musician credited with popularizing the shehnai, a subcontinental wind instrument of the oboe class. While the shehnai had long held importance as a folk instrument played primarily [schooled] in traditional ceremonies, Khan is credited with elevating its status and bringing it to the concert stage.

question: Under which article of the Indian constitution, the Parliament enacts a Delimitation Act after every Census?
solution:
Process of Delimitation: Under Article 82, the Parliament enacts a Delimitation Act after every Census. Under Article 170, States also get divided into territorial constituencies as per Delimitation Act after every Census. Once the Act is in force, the Union government sets up a Delimitation Commission.

The first delimitation exercise was carried out by the President (with the help of the Election Commission) in 1950-51. There was no delimitation after the 1981 and 1991 Censuses.

question: The 'Garibi Hatao' slogan was introduced in which five-year plan (FYP)?
solution: Garibi Hatao desh bachavo (meaning 'Abolish Poverty rescue the country') was the slogan of Indira Gandhi's 1971 election. It was introduced in the Fifth five-year plan spanning 1974 to 1979 with objectives of increasing employment level, reducing poverty and attaining self-reliance.

question: Which female ruler ordered coins to be minted with her title as Pillar of Women and Queen of the Times?
solution:
The fifth Mamluk dynasty ruler, history deems Razia Sultan as one of the very few female rulers in the history of Islamic civilizations across the world. During her reign, she ordered coins be minted with her title as "Pillar of Women, Queen of the Times, Sultan Razia, daughter of Shamsuddin Iltumish."

Razia refused to be addressed as 'Sultana,' the term that would be used to address her according to her gender. Sultana meant "wife or mistress of a Sultan (ruler)."

question: In February 2024, who among the following veteran composer has been awarded the Lakshminarayana International Award?
solution: Pyarelal Sharma, one half of the iconic composer duo Laxmikant-Pyarelal, has been felicitated with the Lakshminarayana International Award. The award was presented to the My Name Is Lakhan composer by musicians L Subramaniam and Kavita Krishnamurthy Subramaniam as part of the Lakshminarayana Global Music Festival.

question: Which of the following is not one of the three 'Domestic Systemically Important Banks' in India?
solution:
Domestic Systemically Important Banks (D-SIBs) in India are banks that the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) considers to be systemically important. The RBI publishes a list of D-SIBs every year.

State Bank of India (SBI): Classified as a D-SIB since 2015

HDFC Bank: Classified as a D-SIB since 2017

ICICI Bank: Classified as a D-SIB since 2016

The RBI issued the framework for D-SIBs in July 2014.

question: In which of the following states is the Tansen Sangeet Samaroh conducted?
solution:
Tansen Sangeet Samaroh is celebrated every year in the month of December in Behat village of Gwalior district, Madhya Pradesh. It is a 4-day musical extravaganza. Artists and music lovers from all over the world gather here to pay tribute to the Great Indian Musical Maestro Tansen.

Tansen, also referred to as Tan Sen or Ramtanu, was a prominent figure of Hindustani classical music. He learned and perfected his art in the northwest region of modern Madhya Pradesh. Tansen was the title given to him by Raja Vikramjit of Gwalior. Tansen was a court musician in the Darbar of Raja Ramachandra of Bandhavgarh (Rewa).

question: Who among the following laid the foundations of the Indian National Movement by founding the Indian Association at Calcutta in 1876?
solution:
· Surendranath Banerjee laid the foundations of the Indian National Movement by founding the Indian Association at Calcutta in 1876 along with Ananda Mohan Bose.

· The objectives of this Association were "promoting by every legitimate means the political, intellectual and material advancement of the people".

question: Gaprindashvili Cup, which was won by India in September 2024, is related to _______.
solution:
India won double gold at the 45th International Chess Federation (FIDE) Chess Olympiad in Budapest, Hungary in September 2024. India won gold in both the men's and women's team competitions.

India also won the Gaprindashvili Cup, which is awarded to the country with the best combined results in both the men's and women's events.

India's men's team was led by D. Gukesh, R. Praggnanandha, Arjun Erigaisi, Vidit Gujrathi, and P. Harikrishna.

India's women's team won the gold medal after defeating Azerbaijan in the final round.

Gukesh D and Arjun Erigaisi also won individual gold medals.

question: Munawar Ali Khan was a classical vocalist of ______gharana.
solution:
Munawar Ali Khan was a Hindustani classical and light classical vocalist of Kasur Patiala Gharana. He created a new raga named Malini Basant and also created many geet, khyal, thumri and ghazal bandishes.

He was the younger son of Ustad Bade Ghulam Ali Khan. He extensively toured across the globe for his performances and had several discs to his credit both in India and abroad.

question: Which of these rivers does not originate in the Himalayas?
solution:
The Mahanadi River originates in the highlands of Chhattisgarh, specifically in the Sihawa hills of the Dhamtari district. It does not originate in the Himalayas.

The other rivers listed do originate in the Himalayas:

Yamuna: Originates from the Yamunotri Glacier in the Himalayas.

Indus: Originates in the Tibetan Plateau, which is considered part of the greater Himalayan region.

Ganga: Originates from the Gangotri Glacier in the Himalayas.

question: Body wall of Coelenterates is
solution: Coelenterates are aquatic organisms, mostly marine and few fresh water forms. They are multicellular, radially symmetrical animals, with tissue grade of organization. Body wall is diploblastic with two layers. An outer ectoderm and inner endoderm are separated by a non-cellular jelly-like substance called mesoglea. It has a central gastrovascular cavity called coelenteron with a mouth surrounded by short tentacles. The tentacles bear stinging cells called cnidoblast or nematocyst.

question: Mahari, Nartaki, and Gotipau are three schools of dance of ______
solution:
Over the centuries, three schools of Odissi dance have developed: Mahari, Nartaki, and Gotipau.

The Mahari tradition is the Devadasi tradition which is the use of women who are attached to deities in the temple.

The Nartaki tradition is the school of Odissi dance, which developed in the royal courts. However, after the 17th century, Odissi declined to great levels, as at that time dancers were considered to be shameless.

As a result of this, no one was ready to learn this dance. Dancing girls were considered to be little more than prostitutes, and the "Anti-Naach" movement of the British brought Odissi dance to near extinction.

question: In Discus Throw, the weight of the discus is fixed at _____ for women.
solution:
The discus throw, where a competitor hurls a heavy disc, was one of the events at the Ancient Olympics. It was introduced in the ancient Greek pentathlon event -- running, long jump, discus throw, javelin throw, and wrestling -- and can be dated back to 708 BC.

The weight of the discus is fixed at 2kg for the men and 1kg for women. The metal disc is basically thrown by an athlete by standing inside a circle with a diameter of 2.5m.

question: Deserts, rain forests, coral reefs and mangroves are features of ______ diversity.
solution:
· Ecological diversity (also called ecosystem diversity) is usually considered to be a type of biodiversity and deals with the variations within or across ecosystems.

· It can encompass factors such as the number of ecological niches, the trophic levels, and/or the physical complexity of the ecosystem(s), in addition to the richness and diversity of the species that inhabit it.

· Deserts, rain forests, coral reefs and mangroves are features of Ecological diversity.

question: Which of the following statements is INCORRECT about current?
option_1: Currents follow vector law of addition.
option_2: The SI unit of electric current is ampere.
option_3: Current through a given area of a conductor is the net charge passing per unit time through the area.
solution:
· Current through a given area of a conductor is the net charge passing per unit time through the area.

· Current is a scalar quantity, hence does not follow vector law of addition.

· The SI unit of electric current is ampere.

question: How many carbon atoms are present in butyric acid?
solution: Butyric acid, also known under the systematic name butanoic acid, is a straight-chain alkyl carboxylic acid with the chemical formula CH₃CH₂CH₂CO₂H. It is an oily, colorless liquid with an unpleasant odor. Isobutyric acid is an isomer. Salts and esters of butyric acid are known as butyrates or butanoates.

question: Some states in India enjoy special powers under certain provisions of Article 371 of the Indian Constitution. The special power is related to ______.
solution: All states in the Indian Union do not have identical powers. Some states enjoy special powers under certain provisions of the Constitution of India (Article 371) due to their peculiar social and historical circumstances. These special powers are especially enjoyed in relation to the protection of land rights of indigenous peoples, their culture and also preferential employment in government services.

question: C.R formula was formulated to solve the political deadlock between the _________ and the Indian National Congress on the independence of British India.
solution:
C. Rajagopalachari's formula was a proposal formulated by Chakravarty Rajagopalachari to solve the political deadlock between the All-India Muslim League and the Indian National Congress on the independence of British India.

Proposals by the CR formula were:

- The Muslim League would join hands with the INC to demand independence from the British.

- Both parties would cooperate and form a provisional government at the centre.

- After the war, a commission would be entrusted with the task of demarcating those areas with an absolute majority of Muslims and a plebiscite to be held in those areas where all the inhabitants (Muslims and non-Muslims) would vote based on adult suffrage whether to form a separate sovereign nation or not.

- In case of partition, joint agreements to be made for the safeguarding of defence, communications and commerce.

- The above terms to come to fruition only if Britain transfers full powers to India.

question: Narma is a type of ______crop grown in the kharif season in semi-arid areas of the country.
solution:
Cotton is a tropical crop grown in kharif season in semi-arid areas of the country. India lost a large proportion of cotton growing area to Pakistan during partition.

However, its acreage has increased considerably during the last 50 years. India grows both short staple (Indian) cotton as well as long staple (American) cotton called 'narma' in north-western parts of the country.

Cotton requires a clear sky during the flowering stage.

question: ΔABC ~ ΔDEF. The areas of Δ ABC and Δ DEF are 40 sq. cm and 90 sq. cm respectively. Find the value of X, if AB = (X - 4) cm and DE = (X + 1) cm.
solution:
Given,

ΔABC ~ ΔDEF

Therefore,

Area of Δ ABC/Area of Δ DEF = (AB/DE)2

√(40/90) = (X - 4)/(X + 1)

2/3 = (X - 4)/(X + 1)

2X + 2 = 3X - 12

X = 12 + 2

X = 14

question: A person travels at the speed of 40 km/h and reaches the office with a delay of 7 minutes from the house. If he had travelled at the speed of 50 km/h, he would have reached 4 minutes delay. Find the distance between home and office.
solution:
Distance = (Speed1 * Speed2)/(Speed1 - Speed2) * Time

= (50 * 40)/ (50 - 40) * (7 - 4)/60

= 10 km

question:
If cosec A =
11_________5
, then the value of (tanA + secA) x cot A is:
solution:
(tanA + secA) x cotA

= 1 + secA x cotA

= 1 + cosecA

= 1 + (11/5)

= 16/5

What is the difference between the number of students from institutes S and U together who are taking chemistry tuitions and biology tuitions?
solution:
Number of students from institutes S and U together who are taking chemistry tuitions

= 170 + 275 = 445

And the number of students from institutes S and U together who are taking biology tuitions

= 440 + 110 = 550

Therefore, difference = 550 - 445 = 105

question:
Following pie - chart shows the quantity of various fruits items present in a supermarket. If 25% of each of the fruits is rotten and total quantity of Peach is 44 kg. Find the quantity of rotten oranges in the supermarket.


https://u1.oliveboard.in/exams/solution/oliveimg/p23668/image015.png
solution:
According to question,

Quantity of Peach = 11% = 44

Quantity of Oranges = 36% = 44/11 * 36 = 144 kg

Quantity of rotten oranges = 25% of 144 = 36 kg

question: Roshan borrows ₹32,500 at a simple interest rate of 15% per annum. After one year, he repays ₹8,400 toward the principal. If Roshan settles the remaining balance, including the interest accrued during the first year, at the end of the second year, how much does he pay in total at that time?
solution:
For 1st year,

P = Rs. 32500, R = 15%, T = 1 year

SI = (P * R * T)/100

=> (32500 * 15 * 1)/100 = Rs. 4875

For 2nd year,

P = 32500 - 8400 = Rs. 24100

R = 15%

T = 1 year

SI = (24100 * 15 * 1)/100 = Rs. 3615

SI for 1st year and 2nd year = 4875 + 3615 = Rs. 8490

Second year pay = Principal + SI

=> 24100 + 8490 = Rs. 32590

question: AB is the chord of a circle such that AB = 12 cm. If the diameter of the circle is 24 cm, then the angle subtended by the chord at the center is:
solution:
O = Center of the circle

Diameter (CD) = 2 * Radius (CO or OD)

Radius = 24/2 = 12 cm

OA = OB = 12 cm

ABO is an equilateral triangle

So, ∠AOB = 60°


https://u1.oliveboard.in/exams/solution/oliveimg/p26815/image014.png

question: The perimeter of a square is equal to the perimeter of a rectangle of length 96 cm and breadth 72 cm. Find the perimeter (in cm) of the semicircle whose diameter is equal to the side of the square.
solution:
The perimeter of the square = The perimeter of the rectangle

4 * Side = 2 * (Length + Breadth)

4 * Side = 2 * (96 + 72)

Side = 84 cm

Diameter = 2 * Radius

The radius of the circle = 84/2 = 42

Hence, the perimeter of the semicircle = πr + 2r

= 22/7 * 42 + 84

= 216 cm

question: The area of the base of the pyramid is 61 sq. cm and height is 15.5 cm, then its volume (in cm3) is: (correct up to two decimal)
solution:
Volume of pyramid = (1/3) * base area * height

Volume = (1/3) * 61 * 15.5

= 315.17 cm3

question: In triangle MNO, P and Q are the midpoints of MN and MO respectively. If PQ = 2.4 cm, then find NO.
solution:
Given that P and Q are the midpoints.

By midpoint theorem,

PQ = NO/2

2.4 * 2 = NO

NO = 4.8 cm

The cost of 4 kg of apples is ₹360. The cost of 7 kg of apples is equal to that of 5 kg of grapes. The cost of 9 kg of grapes is equal to that of 10 kg of oranges. The cost of 5 kg of oranges is equal to that of 3 kg of pears. What is the cost (in ₹) of 10 kg of pears?
solution:
Cost of 4 kg of apples = ₹360

Cost of 5 kg of grapes = cost of 7 kg of apples = 7*360/4 = 630

Cost of 10 kg of oranges = cost of 9 kg of grapes = 9*630/5 = 1134

Cost of 3 kg of pears = cost of 5 kg of oranges = 5*1134/10 = 567

Cost of 10 kg of pears = 10 * 567/3 = ₹1890

question:
Directions: The following histogram shows the number of students in a various weight group.

The ratio of number of students in weight category 45 - 50 kg to that of in weight category 65 - 70 kg respectively is:


https://u1.oliveboard.in/exams/solution/oliveimg/p19216/image001.png
solution:
Number of students in weight category 45 - 50 kg = 15

Number of students in weight category 65 - 70 kg = 10

Required ratio = 15: 10 = 3: 2

question: If Jaya has some amount of money in her bank account and she spent 20% on transport and 25% on education and 13% on rent, then she left with Rs. 1260, then what amount money she has initially in her bank account?

P, Q and R can do a piece of work in 52 days, 26 days and 78 days respectively. Q started the work. P joined him after 3 days. If R joined them after 10 days from the beginning of the work and along with P and Q completed the rest part of work, then for how many days did Q work?
solution:
Let total work = LCM of 52, 26, and 78 = 156 units

Efficiency of P = 156/52 = 3 units per day

Efficiency of Q = 156/26 = 6 units per day

Efficiency of R = 156/78 = 2 units per day

Work done by Q in 3 days = 3 * 6 = 18 units

Work done by P and Q in 7 days = 7 * 9 = 63 units

Remaining work = 156 - 81 = 75 units

Remaining work done by P, Q, and R together in 75/11 = 6(9/11) days

So, Q worked for 3 + 7 + 6(9/11) = 16(9/11) days

question: If cos β = m/n, then find the value of cot β.
solution:
Cos β = m/n = B/H

H2 = B2 + P2

P2 = n2 - m2

P = √(n2 - m2)

Cot β = B/P

= m/√(n2 - m2)

question: (345 + 346 + 347 + 348 + 349) is divisible by:
solution:
(345 + 346 + 347 + 348 + 349)

= 345(30 + 31 + 32 + 33 + 34)

= 345(1 + 3 + 9 + 27 + 81)

= 345 * 121

The number '121' is divisible by 11. So the given number is also divisible by 11.

question:
Study the graph to answer following question.

How much percent more is spent on medicine and rent than on Petrol, cloth and food?


https://u1.oliveboard.in/exams/solution/oliveimg/p13676/image005.png
solution:
Amount spent on medicine and rent in degrees = 77.5⁰ + 109.5⁰ = 187⁰

Amount spent on petrol, cloth and food = 50⁰ + 42⁰ + 81⁰ = 173⁰

Desired % = (187 - 173)*100/173 = 1400/173 = 8(16/173)%

question: A thief steals at 4:30 am and starts moving at the speed of 80 km/h. At 6:00 am the thief is discovered and police start chasing him at the speed of 104 km/h. At what time will the police be able to catch the thief?
solution:
Distance = Speed * Time

Distance travel by thief in 1 hour and 30 minutes = 80 * 90/60

= 120 km

Time = 120/ (104 - 80)

= 5 hours

Hence, the required time = 6 am + 5 hours = 11:00 am

question:
Select the most appropriate ANTONYM of the word 'obscure' in the given sentence and choose the correct option.

The damage to the car was evident from the large dent and scratches along its side.
solution:
"Obscure" means unclear, hidden, or difficult to understand or perceive, while "evident" means clear, obvious, or easily seen. So, the two words can be used as antonyms of each other. Hence, (b) is the correct answer.

Damage: This refers to physical harm or injury caused to something, in this case, the car.

Dent: This refers to a hollow or depression formed by a blow or pressure, typically on a surface such as metal or wood.

Scratches: These are marks or cuts made on a surface, typically as a result of something sharp or abrasive coming into contact with it.

question:
Select the option that can be used as a one-word substitute for the given group of words.

A person who draws or produces maps
solution: The word 'horticulture' means 'the art or practice of garden cultivation and management', 'invigilator' means 'one who supervises in the examination hall' and 'florist' means 'a person who sells and arranges cut flowers'. Hence, the answer is option c) 'cartographer' which means 'a person who draws or produces maps'.

question:
In the following question, a statement has been given with highlighted text. Select the option that replaces the text with correct idiom or phrase.

The case is turning out to be an unsuccessful pursuit of the killer.
solution:
A wild goose chase- complicated or lengthy and usually unsuccessful pursuit or search.

The whole nine yards- everything possible or available.

Jump on the bandwagon- join others in doing or supporting something fashionable or likely to be successful.

Under the nose- directly in front of someone.

Among the given options, the phrase/idiom that matches the meaning of the highlighted phrase is option (a), 'a wild goose chase'.

Hence, the correct answer is option (a).

question:
Select the option that can be used as a one-word substitute for the given group of words.

A speech or piece of writing that praises someone or something highly, especially a tribute to someone who has just died
solution: 'Epitaph' means a phrase or form of words written in memory of a person who has died, especially as an inscription on a tombstone; 'Eulogy' means a speech or piece of writing that praises someone or something highly, especially a tribute to someone who has just died; 'vilification' means abusively disparaging speech or writing; 'denunciation' means a public condemnation of someone or something. According to the meanings mentioned above, b) is the correct answer.

question:
Select the correctly spelt word to fill in the blank.

I need to improve how I speak; my ___ is so faulty.
solution:
Option (c) has the correctly spelt word. Hence, (c) is the correct answer.

'Pronunciation' means the formal or informal way in which a word is made to sound when spoken.

question:

The teacher addressed the student's inappropreate behaviour during class.
solution: Option (b) is the incorrectly spelt word. The correct spelling is "inappropriate" which means something that is not suitable or proper in a given context.

question:
Select the most appropriate synonym of the given word.

Haste
solution:
Haste: excessive speed or urgency of movement or action; hurry.

Thus, the synonym of 'Haste' is 'Hurry'.

Therefore, the correct answer is: (a) Hurry.

WordMeaning

question:
Select the most appropriate SYNONYM to replace the underlined word.

Despite his young age, James was already a/an accomplished pianist, having won several prestigious awards.
solution:
"Accomplished" means highly trained or skilled in a particular activity. 'Competent' means having the necessary ability, knowledge, or skill to do something successfully. So, the two words can be used as synonyms of each other. Hence, (d) is the correct answer.

Struggled: To exert oneself physically or mentally in order to overcome a difficulty or challenge.

Inept: Lacking skill or ability, often resulting in incompetence.

Unfinished: Not completed or concluded; incomplete.

question:
Select the most appropriate meaning of the boldened idiom.

They have decided to turn the tide and change their strategy for better results.
solution: The idiom "turn the tide" means to reverse the general course of events. Hence, (b) is the correct answer.

question:
Select the most appropriate ANTONYM of the given word.

Malicious
solution:
Malicious: characterized by malice; intending or intended to do harm.

Benevolent: having a desire to do good.

As per the meanings, both words are opposite to each other. Hence, option (a) is the answer.

Baleful: threatening harm; menacing.

Vitriolic: filled with bitter criticism or malice.

Rancorous: characterized by bitterness or resentment.

question:
Rearrange the parts of the sentence in the correct order.

(P) Interested in religion

(Q) His parents had been 'slightly religious'

(R) He said that he had never been

(S) Although he had attended a church school and
solution:
The correct order to form a meaningful sentence is SQRP. Part (S) starts by providing context, mentioning the individual's attendance at a church school. Part (Q) follows the context of attending a church school and introduces information about the individual's parents and their religious inclination. Accordingly, SQ forms a necessary pair. Part (R) then moves on to the individual's own statement about his religious beliefs. Part (P) reveals an individual's lack of interest in religion. The sentence presents a contrast between an individual's upbringing and his personal beliefs. Hence, (b) is the correct answer.

The complete sentence is: Although he had attended a church school and his parents had been 'slightly religious', he said that he had never been interested in religion.

question: Select the correct sentence in passive voice from the following options.
option_1: The horror movie had been directed by Steven.
option_3: Steven had directed the horror movie.
option_4: Steven would have been directing the horror movie.
solution:
In passive voice, the subject of the sentence receives the action rather than performing it. Option (a) is in passive voice because the subject (the horror movie) is receiving the action (being directed) by Steven. Hence, (a) is the correct answer.

The rest of the options are in the active voice.

question:
Directions:

Directions [Set of 5 Questions]: In the following passage, some words have been deleted. Read the passage carefully and select the most appropriate option to fill in each blank.

Regular exercise plays a crucial role in maintaining hormone health by promoting balance and efficiency within the endocrine system. Physical activity (1)_____ the release of hormones such as endorphins, which contribute to mood regulation and stress reduction. Additionally, exercise helps to (2)____ insulin levels, aiding in the management of blood sugar levels and reducing the (3)____ of insulin resistance. Moreover, regular exercise can (4) _____ the production of growth hormone, which is essential for muscle growth and repair. Overall, incorporating exercise into one's routine is (5) _____ for optimising hormone health and overall well-being.



Select the most appropriate option to fill in blank no. 1.
solution: The most appropriate option to fill in blank no. 1 is "stimulates." The sentence discusses how physical activity affects hormone release. The word "stimulates" accurately conveys the idea of promoting or triggering the release of hormones, such as endorphins. It suggests that exercise encourages the body to produce these hormones, contributing to mood regulation and stress reduction. Other options are not suitable for the blank. 'Speculates' means to form a theory or conjecture without firm evidence. 'Condemns' means to express strong disapproval of. 'Contemplates' means to think about or consider something deeply. Hence, (a) is the correct answer.

question:
Directions:

Directions [Set of 5 Questions]: In the following passage, some words have been deleted. Read the passage carefully and select the most appropriate option to fill in each blank.

Regular exercise plays a crucial role in maintaining hormone health by promoting balance and efficiency within the endocrine system. Physical activity (1)_____ the release of hormones such as endorphins, which contribute to mood regulation and stress reduction. Additionally, exercise helps to (2)____ insulin levels, aiding in the management of blood sugar levels and reducing the (3)____ of insulin resistance. Moreover, regular exercise can (4) _____ the production of growth hormone, which is essential for muscle growth and repair. Overall, incorporating exercise into one's routine is (5) _____ for optimising hormone health and overall well-being.



Select the most appropriate option to fill in blank no. 2.
solution: The most appropriate option to fill in blank no. 2 is "regulate." The sentence discusses how exercise helps in managing insulin levels. The word "regulate" accurately conveys the idea of controlling or adjusting insulin levels, contributing to the management of blood sugar levels. It suggests that exercise plays a role in maintaining stable insulin levels, which is crucial for overall health. Other options are not suitable for the blank. 'Ponder' means to think about something carefully. 'Mediate' means to intervene or facilitate a resolution between two parties. 'Pacify' means to calm or soothe. Hence, (a) is the correct answer.

question:
Directions:

Directions [Set of 5 Questions]: In the following passage, some words have been deleted. Read the passage carefully and select the most appropriate option to fill in each blank.

Regular exercise plays a crucial role in maintaining hormone health by promoting balance and efficiency within the endocrine system. Physical activity (1)_____ the release of hormones such as endorphins, which contribute to mood regulation and stress reduction. Additionally, exercise helps to (2)____ insulin levels, aiding in the management of blood sugar levels and reducing the (3)____ of insulin resistance. Moreover, regular exercise can (4) _____ the production of growth hormone, which is essential for muscle growth and repair. Overall, incorporating exercise into one's routine is (5) _____ for optimising hormone health and overall well-being.



Select the most appropriate option to fill in blank no. 3.
solution: The most appropriate option to fill in blank no. 3 is "risk." The sentence discusses how exercise helps in reducing the risk of insulin resistance. The word "risk" accurately conveys the idea of potential harm or negative consequences, suggesting that exercise contributes to lowering the likelihood of developing insulin resistance. Other options are not suitable for the blank. 'Accident' refers to an unforeseen event causing harm or damage. 'Fluke' refers to something happening by chance or luck. 'Stroke' refers to a sudden interruption of blood supply to the brain. Hence, (b) is the correct answer.

question:
Directions:

Directions [Set of 5 Questions]: In the following passage, some words have been deleted. Read the passage carefully and select the most appropriate option to fill in each blank.

Regular exercise plays a crucial role in maintaining hormone health by promoting balance and efficiency within the endocrine system. Physical activity (1)_____ the release of hormones such as endorphins, which contribute to mood regulation and stress reduction. Additionally, exercise helps to (2)____ insulin levels, aiding in the management of blood sugar levels and reducing the (3)____ of insulin resistance. Moreover, regular exercise can (4) _____ the production of growth hormone, which is essential for muscle growth and repair. Overall, incorporating exercise into one's routine is (5) _____ for optimising hormone health and overall well-being.



Select the most appropriate option to fill in blank no. 4.
solution: The most appropriate option to fill in blank no. 4 is "support." The sentence discusses how regular exercise can aid the production of growth hormones. The word "support" accurately conveys the idea of aiding or assisting in the production of growth hormones, suggesting that exercise plays a role in facilitating this process. Other options are not suitable for the blank. 'Discover' means to find or uncover something previously unknown. 'Design' refers to planning or creating something with a specific purpose. 'Epitomise' means to embody or represent the perfect example of something. Hence, (b) is the correct answer.

question:
Directions:

Directions [Set of 5 Questions]: In the following passage, some words have been deleted. Read the passage carefully and select the most appropriate option to fill in each blank.

Regular exercise plays a crucial role in maintaining hormone health by promoting balance and efficiency within the endocrine system. Physical activity (1)_____ the release of hormones such as endorphins, which contribute to mood regulation and stress reduction. Additionally, exercise helps to (2)____ insulin levels, aiding in the management of blood sugar levels and reducing the (3)____ of insulin resistance. Moreover, regular exercise can (4) _____ the production of growth hormone, which is essential for muscle growth and repair. Overall, incorporating exercise into one's routine is (5) _____ for optimising hormone health and overall well-being.



Select the most appropriate option to fill in blank no. 5.
solution: The most appropriate option to fill in blank no. 5 is "vital." The sentence discusses the importance of incorporating exercise into one's routine for optimising hormone health and overall well-being. The word "vital" accurately conveys the idea of something being essential or crucial. It suggests that exercise is indispensable for maintaining hormone health and overall well-being. Other options are not suitable for the blank. 'Conspicuous' means easily noticeable or prominent. 'Valiant' means brave or courageous. 'Shivery' means trembling or shivering due to cold or fear. Hence, (d) is the correct answer.

question:
Select the most appropriate synonym of the given word.

Contemplate
solution:
'Contemplate' means to look thoughtfully for a long time. 'Ponder' means to think about (something) carefully, especially before making a decision or reaching a conclusion. So, the two words can be used as synonyms of each other. Hence (b) is the correct answer.

Doubtful- feeling uncertain about something.

Creepy- causing an unpleasant feeling of fear or unease.

Defiant- someone or something that resists behaving or conforming to what is asked or expected.

question:
The following sentence has been split into three segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error. If the sentence is error free, mark 'No error' as your answer.

She don't like/ going to the gym/ in the morning.
solution:
The segment that contains a grammatical error is 'She don't like'.

The error is related to the subject-verb agreement issue.

"Don't", which is a contraction of "do not", is used with plural subjects or second person singular (you). For singular subjects (like "she"), the correct contraction is singular "doesn't" (does not).

The correct phrase should be "She doesn't like," indicating a negative preference. Hence, (b) is the correct answer.

The correct sentence is: She doesn't like going to the gym in the morning.

Note:

Subject-Verb Agreement: Matching up singular or plural subjects with singular or plural forms of a verb is part of the process called agreement. This can be understood better by the examples given: - "She likes cooking." [singular subject and verb] -- "They like to cook vegetables." [plural subject and verb]

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been underlined. Select the option that contains an error.

Two hundred metres are a short distance for a professional sprinter to run in less than ten seconds.
solution:
The verb "are" in option b) is incorrect.

When a plural noun denotes a specific amount or quantity, it is considered singular. In this sentence, "two hundred metres" represents a specific length and should be treated as a singular entity.

Therefore, the verb used here should be singular in nature ("is") instead of the plural verb "are."

The correct sentence should be: Two hundred metres is a short distance for a professional sprinter to run in less than ten seconds.

Hence, option (b) is the answer.

question: Select the sentence with the appropriate use of preposition.
option_1: RTGS service will be unavailable since 14 hours at Sunday.
option_2: RTGS service will be unavailable for 14 hours at Sunday.
option_3: RTGS service will be unavailable for 14 hours on Sunday.
option_4: RTGS service will be unavailable for 14 hours in Sunday.
solution:
In the given sentence, '14 hours' indicates a time period. We usually use the preposition 'for' to indicate a time period. The preposition 'on' is used before a specific day (like Monday, Sunday, etc.). According to this, the sentence in option (c) represents the sentence with the appropriate use of prepositions.

Hence, option (c) is the correct answer.

At: used to show an exact position or particular place.

For: used to show an amount of time or distance.

On: used to show when something happens.

In: inside a container, place, or area, or surrounded or closed off by something.

Note:

A Preposition is a word placed before a noun or a pronoun or a noun equivalent (pronoun, adverb, gerund, infinitive, adverbial clause, or any clause that can be used as the object of the preposition) and shows a relationship in space or time or a logical relationship between two or more people, places, or things in a sentence.

Examples

I. The teacher scolded the child for being late.

II. We're going to a party.

· The words in bold are called prepositions because they normally take a position before (pre) a noun/pronoun or a noun equivalent (pronoun, adverb, gerund, infinitive, adverbial clause, or any clause that can be used as the object of the preposition.

· The noun/pronoun which is used with a preposition is called its Object.

question:
The following sentence has been split into three segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error. If the sentence is error free, mark 'No error' as your answer.

Strangely, never once / they did mention the / mysteries of those deaths.
solution:
When the adverb of time (always, never, hardly, seldom, ever, sometimes) is used before the verbs that they modify, and if these adverbs come at the beginning of the sentence, the sentence takes inversion form which means the helping verb comes before the subject.

(Syntax: Never + helping verb + subject + main verb).

So, 'they did mention' should be replaced with 'did they mention'.

Hence, option (b) is correct.

question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence. In case no improvement is needed, select 'No improvement required'.

The authority said that the restaurants could no longer add service charge at default.
solution:
The phrase 'at default' is incorrect. The phrases of defaults are 'in default' (guilty of failing to repay a loan or appear in a law court) and 'by default' (If something happens by default, it happens only because something else might have prevented it or changed it has not happened). For example:

The company is already in default on its loans.

I would rather pay the individuals than let the money go to the State by default.

So, the most appropriate choice would be 'by default'. This implies that now there must be a rule because of which restaurants can no longer add a service charge. Hence, option (b) is the correct answer.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can replace the bracketed segment in the given sentence.

The company intends to (launched in) its new product line at the trade show next week.
solution:
The most appropriate option that can replace the bracketed segment is 'launch'. The infinitive marker 'to' is usually followed by the base form of the verb. But the verb 'launched' (past participle) is not in the base form. Accordingly, the base form 'launch' (option (a)) should replace the verb 'launched'.

Option (b) is incorrect as it does not rectify the error present in the original sentence. This option also does not use base form after 'to'.

Option (c) is also incorrect as it uses the present tense form 'launches' in place of the base form.

Option (d) is incorrect as well. The use of "have" suggests the present perfect tense, which is not appropriate here. The sentence discusses a future intention (next week), which requires the simple infinitive form "to launch". Hence, (a) is the correct answer.

The correct sentence is: The company intends to launch its new product line at the trade show next week.

NOTE:

"Infinitive: The infinitive is the base form of a verb, often preceded by to.

Consider the sentences given below:

· To err is human. [like a noun, the infinitive 'to err' is the subject of the verb 'is']

· My father likes to cook. [like a noun, the infinitive 'to cook' is the object of the verb 'likes']

· To vote in elections is our right. [the infinitive 'to vote', like a noun, is the subject of the verb 'is', but, like a verb, it also takes an object (elections)]

· Radha went to the lake to fetch water. [the infinitive 'to fetch', like a noun, is the object of the verb 'went', but, like a verb, it also takes an object (water)]

· The above sentences illustrate various ways in which infinitives are used. It can both act as a noun and a verb."

"Participle: A word formed from a verb (e.g. going, gone, being, been) and used as an adjective (e.g. working woman, burnt toast) or a noun (e.g. good breeding). In English, participles are also used to make compound verb forms (e.g. is going, has been). Consider the sentences given below:

Dancing at the party, the women fell on the ground.

Encouraged by her parents, Rita went on to pursue her passion.

The highlighted word in the first sentence is of the form Verb + ing and is used as a present participle. It is used to denote an action that is going on or incomplete or imperfect.

The highlighted word in the second sentence is of the form verb + ed. It is used as a past participle. It denotes the completed action or state of the thing spoken of.

A past participle ends with the following: -ed, -d, -t, -en, or -n.

One should take great care and never get confused between a gerund and a present participle. They use the same forms but perform different functions: a gerund is a verbal noun, while a present participle is a verbal adjective."

question:
Select the most appropriate option to fill in the blank.

My watch is missing, and I suspect _________ has stolen it.
solution:
The sentence requires an indefinite pronoun to fill the blank because they refer to things or people in general instead of being specific or definite. The speaker doesn't know who specifically has stolen his/her watch. The speaker just suspects that it has been stolen.

'Themselves' is a reflexive pronoun. These pronouns show that the action done by the subject is directed toward not anyone else but the subject. So, it cannot fill the blank. So, option a) is incorrect.

'Each' is treated as singular but is used to denote every one of two or more people or things. So, option b) is incorrect.

'This' is a demonstrative pronoun. It cannot fill in the given blank. So, option c) is incorrect.

'Someone' is an indefinite pronoun that means any unspecified or unknown person. It is a fit word to fill the blank since it is a singular indefinite pronoun.

The correct sentence is: My watch is missing, and I suspect someone has stolen it.

Hence, option d) is correct.

Note: Indefinite Pronouns: Indefinite pronouns refer to people, places and things in a general way (do not talk about any specific person, place or thing). Some typical indefinite pronouns are: all, another, any, anybody/anyone, anything, each, everybody/everyone, everything, few, many, nobody, none, one, several, some, somebody/someone.

Demonstrative pronouns: Demonstrative pronouns are used to emphasise which thing (of multiple possibilities) you are talking about. This, that, these, and those are demonstrative pronouns. Example: "These are books, I love to read."

Reflexive Pronouns: Reflexive pronouns include myself, himself, herself, itself, ourselves, yourselves, and themselves. These are used to refer back to the subject of the clause in which they are used: She hurt herself in the eye.
